subHints.text: Using the function $$\lim_{x\toa} \frac{1}{{\left(x-a\right)}^n}$$, what is $$n$$ in /lim{x,-3**-,1/(x+3)**4}?

title: Finding /lim{x,-3**-,1/(x+3)**4}
text: Given that $$n$$ is a positive even integer, what is the limit?
speech: Given that  n  is a positive even integer, what is the limit?
pacedSpeech: is a positive even integer, what is the limit?

title: Explanation
text: From the function $$\lim_{x\toa} \frac{1}{{\left(x-a\right)}^n}$$, we know that $$n$$ $$=$$ $$4$$ in /lim{x,-3**-,1/(x+3)**4}. According to the Infinite Limits from Positive Integers Theorem, if $$n$$ is a positive even integer, then $$\lim_{x\toa} \frac{1}{{\left(x-a\right)}^n}=+\infty$$. Since $$4$$ is a positive even integer, this means that /lim{x,-3**-,1/(x+3)**4}=+inf.
